manuscript.title: Mazharü'n-Nûr
manuscript.author: Münîbullâh b. İnâyetullâh el-Hüseynî (d. 1174/1760)
manuscript.notes: Undated copy of a theological text (akâid ve kelâm) by Münîbullâh b. İnâyetullâh el-Hüseynî (d. 1174/1760). The manuscript was left incomplete (sonu yarım bırakılmıştır — 'left unfinished at the end'). A one-page index (fihrist) is noted at the beginning. The manuscript bears the vakıf seal of Ahmet Siyahi Efendi on f. 1a (1a'da Ahmet Siyahi Efendi'nin vakıf mührü vardır). The manuscript transferred from the Halîdiyye Medresesi (Halîdiyye Medresesi devren). The catalogue cites GAL Supplement II, p. 616 (Brockelmann's Geschichte der arabischen Litteratur, Supplement vol. II) for the author identification. Cataloguer: Abdullah Seçgin.

paper_decoration.summary: A single-programme Ottoman theological manuscript with a concentrated luxury decorative scheme at the opening. The first page margin bears halkârî decoration (ilk sayfa kenarı halkârî — a confirmed YEK descriptive phrase for first-page margin halkâr). A nefis müzehhep serlevha (finely illuminated headpiece) opens the text. The cedveller are described as renkli müzehhep (colored/illuminated ruling lines), and word-beginnings (söz başları) are in red (kırmızı). The text has a patterned (desenli) paper binding cover (desenli kâğıt kaplı cilt). The halkâr is confined to the opening page margin; the rest of the manuscript is plain with colored illuminated ruling. This is a characteristic Ottoman programme: concentrated luxury at the opening, plain thereafter.
paper_decoration.distribution_notes: Halkâr confined to the first-page margin (ilk sayfa kenarı halkârî). Nefis müzehhep serlevha at the opening. Renkli müzehhep cedveller throughout. Word-beginnings in red throughout. Decorated paper binding covers (not page decoration).

workshop_attribution.date_range_ce: post-1760 (terminus post quem: death of author)
key_indicators: Halîdiyye Medresesi provenance situates the manuscript in a Kastamonu regional institutional context
Patterned paper binding covers (desenli kâğıt kaplı cilt) are characteristic of provincial Ottoman binding production
Concentrated luxury at the opening (halkâr + müzehhep serlevha + renkli cedvel) without full-codex decoration is consistent with a provincial commission or a manuscript produced at moderate expense
cross_tradition_caveats: Undated manuscript: the author died 1174/1760, giving only a terminus post quem; no colophon date available

The halkâr is limited to the first-page margin — a narrower programme than high-quality Istanbul productions; this may indicate either provincial production or an economy of effort in a less prestigious commission
Confidence is limited (0.45) by the absence of a date, colophon, and the unresolved halkâr identification at screenshot resolution

paper.decoration: Halkâr on first-page margin; illuminated headpiece; colored ruling throughout

ruling.system: Renkli müzehhep cedveller (colored illuminated ruling lines)
ruling.description: The cedvels are described as renkli müzehhep — colored and illuminated ruling lines framing the text block. In the IIIF screenshot (p005) gold cetvels are clearly visible framing the text blocks on both pages. The specific color combination of the ruling is not enumerated in the catalogue beyond 'renkli' (colored).

binding.cover_description: Mıkleplı, desenli kâğıt kaplı cilt (miklep flap binding with patterned paper covers)
binding.notes: Patterned paper covers (desenli kâğıt kaplı) — a binding type using decorated paper on the boards rather than leather. Common in Ottoman provincial production and for lower-status copies. The miklep (flap) is standard for Ottoman bindings.

elements.motif: Gold cetvels and faint margin decoration
elements.description: Gold cetvels frame the text block on both pages of the bifolio. The margin area shows faint tonal variation that could indicate subtle halkâr or plain paper, but resolution is insufficient to distinguish the two. The specific first-page margin halkâr (ilk sayfa kenarı halkârî) documented in the catalogue would appear on the opening page, not on p005.
elements.location: Frame lines around text block, both pages

folio_analyses.notes: The identification as probable rests on the catalogue description: 'ilk sayfa kenarı halkârî' is a specific, technically precise phrase confirmed as genuine in YEK Batch 3 cataloguing conventions (see terminology-reference.md). The visibility of gold cetvels and body-text layout at p005 is consistent with a manuscript where the decorative concentration is at the opening.

terms_used.english: Ilk sayfa kenarı halkârî: a confirmed YEK cataloguing phrase meaning 'the first-page margin bears halkâr decoration.' This is a location-specific descriptor that confines the halkâr programme to the opening folio's margin only. Confirmed as a genuine decorated-paper phrase in YEK Batch 3 (Kastamonu 1569).

Nefis müzehhep serlevha: a finely worked (nefis = delicate, refined) illuminated (müzehhep) headpiece (serlevha) at the opening of a text. Standard luxury marker for Ottoman theological and literary manuscripts.

Renkli müzehhep cedvel: colored and illuminated ruling lines. A step above plain gold cetvels — the lines are colored with multiple inks (gold plus at least one additional color) and the description 'müzehhep' (illuminated/gilded) implies the gold is applied in the context of an illuminated programme rather than plain ruling.

Vakıf mührü: the stamped seal of a waqf (pious endowment), applied to manuscripts to record their transfer to an endowed institution. The seal of Ahmet Siyahi Efendi on f. 1a documents this manuscript's entry into the Halîdiyye Medresesi endowment.

provenance.donor: Ahmet Siyahi Efendi (vakıf mührü on f. 1a)
provenance.waqf: Halîdiyye Medresesi — transferred to Kastamonu Yazma Eser Kütüphanesi
provenance.notes: The manuscript bears the vakıf seal (mührü) of Ahmet Siyahi Efendi on f. 1a, recording its endowment to (or transfer through) the Halîdiyye Medresesi in Kastamonu. The manuscript was subsequently transferred (devren) to the Kastamonu Yazma Eser Kütüphanesi where it is now held. YEK ID: 455794. IIIF ID: 0000000449520. Cataloguer: Abdullah Seçgin.
